I Can't Recommend Nekoweb, A Neocities Alternative

Author: êï£ C M D R ‚ñë NOVA êï£
Published: 15 Oct 2024


Today I woke up, and, like I do, I checked my ‚Äúdaily report‚Äù bot e-mail, and noticed something ‚Ä¶ strange. According to the Neocities subreddit, the person behind Neocities had written, a year ago, some positive thinking about AI (which, I‚Äôm not sure can be fully judged a year later, since it‚Äôs only gotten extremely bad, this year). In response, some users were suggesting Nekoweb as an alternative for people who don‚Äôt want to be potentially affiliated with someone who endorses Sam Altman. And then I stumbled into an issue, and the strangest people I‚Äôve met this week (so far).

Nekoweb is much like Neocities, and even more-so, it offers services that Neocities doesn‚Äôt. At first glance, this seems pretty awesome. You have more storage space, more bandwith, access to Git, FTP, and it‚Äôs even got framework for deploying your site with a static generator (like Jekyll). ‚ÄúSweet.‚Äù I thought, this could really make my life easier, instead of pushing through Github, to Neocities, right?

There‚Äôs just one problem.

Nekoweb requires you reveal all personal information to them, in order to register an account. VPNs are not allowed.

The only other place online, thus far, that I‚Äôve had any issue with using my VPN, be it via Proton‚Äôs subscription service that I use for e-mail, or Apple‚Äôs built-in VPN, has been Misskey‚Äôs flagship server (that auto-blocks Western users from registering). Not even Activision blocks you from using a VPN while playing their highly competitive shooters, Call of Duty.

So, like ya do, I joined their Discord, curious, a little bummed. Thinking, there‚Äôs no way I have to turn off something completely related to my own online safety and privacy just to make an account here, right?

Wrong.

I don‚Äôt feel the need to post direct screenshots, since this website is seen by quite a few more people than my Mastodon account, so I‚Äôll just quote the person who immediately replied to me when I asked, ‚ÄúSo why can‚Äôt I have my VPN turned on when I‚Äôm making an account?‚Äù

User / Supporter / or maybe even dev? responds:

why are you using VPN to register an account?

we had spammers use VPN to comment hate stuff on users guestbooks

probably why [team member affiliated with Nekoweb] doesn‚Äôt allow vpn

The Nekoweb team member responds,

abuse prevention

Flabbergasted, blown-away, I respond, ‚ÄúI use a VPN provided by Proton‚Äôs subscription service that comes along with their e-mail, entirely just for privacy lol‚Äù

To which the first user replies, again,

well in order to register you need proper internet connection and no VPN.

‚Ä¶

PROPER INTERNET CONNECTION???

It was at this point I kind of fell off and spiraled a bit, implied neither of them know what they‚Äôre doing, and left.

So, no, I absolutely wouldn‚Äôt recommend you use Nekoweb as an alternative to Neocities, if that‚Äôs what you‚Äôre looking for. How people who don‚Äôt even know what a VPN does, or is used for by average people, ended up making an entire web service, is wild, ridiculous, and makes absolutely no sense. And I get the impression that they don‚Äôt want new users, or any subscription money for that matter. Which is fine. They aren‚Äôt getting any from me.

For anyone else, who might be a little more rationally inclined, why use a VPN?

It‚Äôs not just for watching shows on Netflix you can‚Äôt get in the US. Some countries are blocked from most internet access and can‚Äôt interact with the outside world, without a VPN. Guess they aren‚Äôt allowed to make websites, either?

Why do I use a VPN? I use one, because I don‚Äôt think every website and provider needs my personal information at all times, every single time I access a domain. I especially don‚Äôt think the developers behind Nekoweb need my personal information, just to make an account on their Neocities clone. Entitled to my data as they may be, if you have a problem with spam and abuse coming from users behind VPNs, and you just ban VPN use, uhm, guys? You know that perpetrators of abuse can just make a new e-mail and do exactly the same thing, without a VPN? They could drive down the street to McDonalds, log on, and continue harassing your users.

And, I‚Äôm sorry, I‚Äôm still reeling over ‚Äúproper internet connection.‚Äù

I‚Äôm just out of words in my brain sauce that would allow me to express how ridiculous that sounds ‚Ä¶ you guys made this web service? For real? You made a whole web service for hosting websites and you don‚Äôt even know the first thing about privacy and safety online?

Holy hell.
